The point of p2p tech is to distribute trust.

You can't distribute trust without consent.

You can't consent without meaningful privacy.

Privacy should be a foundational element in any p2p stack, not a challenge, or a footnote, or a "maybe we will get to this in the future".

976063018298675200.text: I’m the first to admit that I don’t have the answers. It needs to be a collaborative and inclusive process. It needs to be more than a discussion of “ethics in design,” and rather an reclamation of design from the apolitical structures of current digital design.

976058771649826816.text: Our digital platforms are so complicated. An almost incomprehensible mesh of practice, interfaces, automation and human beings. Maybe we need something to critically examine our industry’s failures – like a National Transportation Safety Board, but for design and engineering.

976058067271012352.text: This idea of ethical design is the true next step – that is, benevolent intentions when designing – allows designers to point at their own work and say, “I’m operating ethically.” It’s the same kind of mindset that produces beliefs like this:https://twitter.com/aral/status/975643691254730752 …

976057022738255874.text: It’s tempting to describe a process of “ethical design” (see: Mike Monterio, @aral, etc). But this does nothing more than help absolve a designer who considers their work ethical. It’s unhelpful without a complete examination and overhaul of the accepted methods of practice.

976055682469388288.text: At the core of our work, we depoliticise and decontextualise interaction design in the pursuit of frictionless, delightful experiences. We must change this, but the discussion just isn’t there yet.

976055029345017856.text:
Design has a political problem that extends from the very surface of aesthetics, and right down to the core practices around decision making processes.

Within the interface, we deploy surveillance disguised as user flow research, non-consensual user testing & design for ‘trust’
